Bethuadahari is a man-made forest with two big water bodies. Very densely covered with trees the area is fenced and clearly separated from human settlement.
The sanctuary covering 67 hectares was established in 1980.

It is flat Gangetic Plain all around.

The Salim Ali trail, inside the forest leads to a pond where rare turtles are preserved. The same pond houses saltwater alligators known as ghariyal. Every morning they come out of the pond as they are fed by forest guards. One has to be here to enjoy the scene.

Animals in the sanctuary are chital or spotted deer, jackal, porcupine, and langur. 

Bird species include parakeets, Indian cuckoos, barbets and other smaller birds. 

Pythons, monitor lizards and gharials are also found.

Among the trees found within the sanctuary are shal, teak, arjun, Indian rosewood, and bamboo.

It is located beside National Highway 34. Therefore, those travelling by car can easily get in. Buses ply on NH 34. 

Those wanting to travel by train from Kolkata take Lalgola-Sealdah Passenger or the Bhagirathi Express from Sealdah and get off at Bethuadahari railway station.

value: directions= This lodge is located in the forest/ sanctuary and directions for reaching the place would be available at the time of booking.
price= Rs. 1,200 per day for a double-bedded room

content= The only way to book a stay in advance at this lodge is through the booking office of the West Bengal Forest Development Corporation in Kolkata, at 6/A, Raja Subodh Mallick Square, 7th floor, Kolkata-700013, and one can get more information by calling their Kolkata number: 033-22370061/62. Booking starts three months in advance against full payment.
directions= This lodge is located outside the sanctuary in a nearby town
